title: If I have a linear regulator, a LM7805. If it is powered from 10V and has a 5V output. its supply current is 100mA. What is the 5V load current, assuming 100% efficiency? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is no 100% efficient LM7805. It is inherently less than 100%. In your scenario the efficiency could never be better than 50%. The approximate equation for currents is Iin = Iout+Iq Where Iq is the quiescent current of the device at zero load. I haven’t looked it up in years but I think it probably around 5–10 mA. There are a number of variants on 78xx series parts so it may different from one to another; I also expect some small differences based on load current. You will find it listed on the spec sheet. Why don’t people ever read them?

You have two contradictory statements in the question. If you assume 100% efficiency, the incoming power and outgoing power are equal. If you have a linear regulator, the input current equals the output current (+ a quiescent current that is used to pet the device itself, and is directed to the ground pin). Do you, by “100% efficiency”, mean power efficiency (if so, not a linear regulator), or that the quiescent current is zero? (If the latter, you have the answer in the question)
